title: Hello2000
author: Hello2000
content: I'm looking to sell usdc for cash upfront as other payment methods aren't as secure for me due to chargebacks etc.. I'm located in Midtown NYC and looking for 1:1 ratio. Looking to do around $5,000 usdc to start off with. If possible can text me at 917-544-4493. Thank you.

comments.author: dimonstration
comments.body: Quote from: Hello2000 on September 24, 2022, 03:13:15 PMI'm looking to sell usdc for cash upfront as other payment methods aren't as secure for me due to chargebacks etc.. I'm located in Midtown NYC and looking for 1:1 ratio. Looking to do around $5,000 usdc to start off with. If possible can text me at 917-544-4493. Thank you.Why not use P2P exchange on CEX like Binance, Kucoin and OKX. Some of this exchange offers free service fee and most them only charge few percentage that less than 1% to the total amount which is very small compared to the risk that you will take on doing a meetup transaction to some random user here.

comments.author: Hello2000
comments.body: On KuCoin you can sell for bank deposit ?

comments.author: alterra57
comments.body: Quote from: Hello2000 on September 24, 2022, 07:45:49 PMOn KuCoin you can sell for bank deposit ?You can't, unless you P2P. And nobody will do it for a 1:1 rate, people are trying to make money.

comments.author: DireWolfM14
comments.body: If you're looking to avoid KYC Bisq is a good choice.  The only issue you're likely to face with Bisq is that all trades must include BTC, so you'll have to trade your USDC for bitcoin, then sell the bitcoin for cash.  In the US you can trade bitcoin for Zelle, which is fairly safe from charge-backs.  Since Bisq requires trade deposits, it tends to deter scammers anyway, so the risk is pretty minor.  It can also facilitate face to face transactions that are pretty safe, again due to the way bisq sends the funds to a 2 of 2 multi-sig wallet.  You can also facilitate selling bitcoin for US Postal Money Orders or Cash by Mail.

comments.author: Bitcoin_Arena
comments.body: If bisq is not user friendly, you can use localcryptos p2p exchange. They also don't require KYC. They support only BTC, ETH, DASH, LTC and BCH, so you are going to convert that USDC to one of those coins and then send them over there - https://localcryptos.com/Bitcoin/United_States/Sell

comments.author: 16xypjnxlrew
comments.body: Quote from: DireWolfM14 on September 26, 2022, 02:00:39 PMIf you're looking to avoid KYC Bisq is a good choice.  The only issue you're likely to face with Bisq is that all trades must include BTC, so you'll have to trade your USDC for bitcoin, then sell the bitcoin for cash.  In the US you can trade bitcoin for Zelle, which is fairly safe from charge-backs.  Since Bisq requires trade deposits, it tends to deter scammers anyway, so the risk is pretty minor.  It can also facilitate face to face transactions that are pretty safe, again due to the way bisq sends the funds to a 2 of 2 multi-sig wallet.  You can also facilitate selling bitcoin for US Postal Money Orders or Cash by Mail.How will he protect himself from an unscrupulous postman who steals that $5,000?

comments.author: geartips
comments.body: If you didn't find anyone yet i will suggest service on instagram username @flypexchangeI use them all the time, no KYC needed and fees are great.. They are super fast tooAnyhow hope i helped cheers
